Title: To the rejected
Description: April 2024

Title: The Easiest Way to Meditate
Description:
Meditation is great ‚Äî most of us can agree on that. But like exercise, it‚Äôs been overcomplicated. There are just so many forms of it: guided, silent, body scans, vipassana, kriyas. There are apps, videos, retreats, books, and self-proclaimed gurus‚Äîeveryone‚Äôs selling their version.

Its benefits have also been oversold. People are led to believe it‚Äôs a one-stop solution for all mental health issues, and at worst, a path to everlasting bliss. Do a week of Vipassana and your mind will be permanently transformed.

I can‚Äôt speak for everyone, but that hasn‚Äôt been my experience.

Meditation, to me, is just a tool to denoise the brain ‚Äî and that‚Äôs become crucial in an age of constant overstimulation. Denoising helps you tune into the present, improves your focus, helps you identify the negative thought patterns, and also, softens their grip.

## Transcendental Meditation

Once I reframed what meditation¬†*is*‚Äîa tool to denoise the brain‚ÄîI had much more realistic expectations. After experimenting with various techniques, I found one that fits perfectly: Transcendental Meditation.

Don't worry, the name makes it sound advanced, but it‚Äôs actually the simplest one I‚Äôve tried.

That said, it‚Äôs promoted by an organization that is borderline scammy (trying too hard to sell something), so good info is weirdly hard to find without paying. But the technique itself? Surprisingly easy and effective.

Here's how to do it:

**Just close your eyes and repeat a simple word or mantra <u>in your mind</u> (like, _om_, _shrim_, or _namah_). It should be pleasant sounding and ideally meaningless. Don‚Äôt try to control your thoughts. If your mind drifts, gently return to repeating the mantra.**

That‚Äôs it. Sit on a chair, sit cross-legged, or lie down, doesn‚Äôt matter. Set a timer for 15‚Äì20 minutes, or go by feel. Do it in a park, or at home; in the morning, evening, or at night.

‚ÄãEverything is up to you. 

## Why it works?

Like I said earlier, meditation is just a way to denoise your brain. Whether you focus on your breath, your body, or a mantra ‚Äî it‚Äôs all aiming for the same outcome.

Repeating a word in your head is especially effective because, oddly enough, **the mind can only focus on one thing at a time**. When you repeat the word, it gently cuts off wandering thoughts. Over time, this starts to clear the mental clutter. Your mind calms down and you become more in tune with the present, and your own thought patterns.

When I practice it, I feel less overwhelmed, more focused, and the urge to doomscroll quiets down. And at night, it‚Äôs incredibly helpful for falling asleep.

If meditation is supposed to be a path to everlasting bliss, then I‚Äôm probably not on it ‚Äî and honestly, that‚Äôs okay.

---

People have claimed all sorts of things about meditation, but in my experience, it's not necessary to explore the depth of consciousness to be reasonably happy. It‚Äôs healthier to approach meditation with more grounded expectations. 

But that's my take.  If you want to transform your mind, you're better off exploring a retreat or something similar.

Title: Everyone Wants to Be a Ghibli Character. So, Why Does It Feel So Wrong?
Description: There‚Äôs a peculiar kind of magic in watching Studio Ghibli films. The kind that doesn‚Äôt just entertain ‚Äî it lingers. It coats your soul like the afternoon light in My Neighbor Totoro, or the silent resilience of Princess Mononoke. It makes you want to touch grass, sip tea slowly, notice the wind, and wonder why we ever stopped paying attention to these things in the first place.

Title: How to Make Your Neural Network Run Faster: An Overview of Optimization Techniques
Description:
Introduction Neural networks are becoming increasingly powerful, but speed remains a crucial factor in real-world applications. Whether you‚Äôre running models on the cloud, edge devices, or personal hardware, optimizing them for speed can lead to faster inference, lower latency, and reduced resource consumption.
In this post, we‚Äôll explore various techniques to accelerate neural networks, from model compression to hardware optimizations. This will serve as a foundation for future deep dives into each method.

Title: .NET AI Community Standup - üîÆ Fortune-Telling with Semantic Kernel
Description:
What do your birth date, time, and place say about your future? In Korea, fortune tellers use complex math to create a perpetual calendar‚Äîbut now, we're giving that tradition a modern .NET twist! üíª‚ú®

Join Bruno and Justin as they summon the powers of Azure OpenAI, Semantic Kernel, and Azure Container Apps dynamic sessions to build an intelligent .NET app that calculates your birth chart and lets an LLM interpret your destiny.

From generating and executing Python code on-the-fly to orchestrating it all with Semantic Kernel, they‚Äôll show live demos, share clever tricks, and spark ideas for your own AI-powered experiences.

Community Links: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/collections/8xymaztyqqe21r

Featuring: Bruno Capuano (@elbruno), Justin Yoo (@justinchronicle)

#dotnet #AI #SemanticKernel #AzureOpenAI #AzureContainerApps

Title: Role Based Authorization in ASP .NET Core (using Identity and JWT)
Description:
In this tutorial we will talk about role based authorization in ASP .NET Core Web API that uses Identity for user management and provides JWT after successful authentication.

In this tutorial I've used the API that was built in my tutorial about JWT/Refresh Token Authentication in ASP .NET Core Web API, feel free to check it out to get the proper understanding about it. In description of this video, you will find the link to the github where I've posted the source code.

JWT Authentication in ASP .NET Core with Refresh Token (.NET 9):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G6eEPPBIkh8

By the end of this video, you‚Äôll have a fully functional authorization system that ensures only authorized users can access specific resources in your API project based on Role claim in JSON web token.
